body:
This shows great improvement in a single game of TS (sorry I can't test more now).
We'll need to stress-test this quite a bit in all mods, but so far bravo and thanks @RoosterDragon!
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4Mag-oGBQNCVmNuWXpDVEtwa3M/view?usp=sharing

Seems like a good idea to me.

Real players can cause similar problems with lots of units selected, but AI
is much better at doing it consistently.

On Sat, Jul 25, 2015 at 9:56 AM, RoosterDragon notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Fixes #8466 https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/8466, #8384
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/8384, #4584
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/4584.
> Issue
> 
> In games with AI, as the game progresses there will start to be lag spikes
> every ~1 second. The spikes get worse with more AI.
> Cause
> 
> AIs re-evaluate their current state at set intervals. For example assigning
> of roles
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/HackyAI.cs#L40-L41
> and updating of squads
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/HackyAI.cs#L46-L47.
> You'll notice both of these are 20/30 ticks - which are both roughly 1
> second.
> 
> Luckily, evaluating AI state is fast.
> 
> What happens then is that the AIs issue new orders to be carried out. In a
> typical case they might issue say 10 orders to one of the squads to attack.
> 
> Luckily, issuing orders is fast.
> 
> These orders are processed during the tick by the order manager
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs#L212
> .
> 
> Luckily, processing orders is fast.
> 
> Each time an order is processed, a hash of the world state must be
> generated for sync purposes
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/7d56209f3b772ea847cc8c9decb4c33cc4210e7d/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs#L213.
> This allows clients to identify the order responsible in the event of a
> desync.
> 
> Unluckily, hashing the world state is extremely slow.
> 
> In games with several AI, a few AI will decide to send orders to their
> squads, each squad needing maybe a dozen orders. They do this all at the
> exact same tick. This results in a flood of orders (say about 50 orders
> instead of the more usual 0-5) to be processed in a single tick. Hashing
> the world state so many times as a result of processing the orders is the
> reason for the lag spike.
> The Fix
> 
> I address this issue by limiting the ability of the AI to generate a flood
> of orders in a single tick. Instead, I spread out the orders over several
> ticks.
> 
> The first commit makes each AI in the game operate on different ticks. In
> games with lots of AI, this prevents them teaming up to make one tick very
> slow.
> 
> The second limits the number of orders an AI can issue per tick. Extra
> orders are queued up and processed on subsequent ticks. This prevents
> spikes from issuing orders to entire squads at once by forcing the AI to
> order each unit on separate ticks.
> 
> This throttling means that orders might be outdated by the time they are
> issued. This seems to work in my testing but somebody who knows how orders
> work better than I do should confirm I'm not introducing a massive chance
> for crashes and/or desyncs.
> Results
> 
> Perf graphs before and after (we care about the teal line representing
> tick_time)
> 
> [image: Perf Graph Comparion]
> https://camo.githubusercontent.com/7e863d40334fff8fbab1237c44c29ee0fec7e587/687474703a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f53553561304c6f2e706e67
> 
> You can check this yourself by just spectating a game with a large number
> of AI. Wait a few minutes until they start attacking each other and the lag
> 
> ## spikes should appear. With this PR they should be prevented.
> 
> You can view, comment on, or merge this pull request online at:
> 
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770
> Commit Summary
> - Avoid multiple AIs all issuing orders in exactly the same tick.
> - Throttle the issuing of orders by the AI.
> 
> File Changes
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/BaseBuilder.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-0 (6)
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/HackyAI.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-1 (52)
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/States/AirStates.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-2 (8)
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/States/GroundStates.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-3 (10)
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/States/ProtectionStates.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-4 (2)
> - _M_ OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/States/StateBase.cs
>   https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770/files#diff-5 (2)
> 
> Patch Links:
> - https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770.patch
> - https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770.diff
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/8770.
This plus #8759 appear to completely fix the common lag spikes.  Great Job!

I've implemented a parameter to process a portion of the queue size rather than a fixed amount per turn in order to reduce the risk of AIs queueing orders at a faster rate than they can issue them as @pchote noted. The default value might need some tuning.

I played this with two local clients and many bots which desynced the game:

```
Exception of type `System.InvalidOperationException`: Out of sync in frame 4705: Blame Tick.
 Compare syncreport.log with other players.
  at OpenRA.Network.OrderManager.OutOfSync (Int32 frame, System.String blame) [0x0001e] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs:63 
  at OpenRA.Network.OrderManager.CheckSync (System.Byte[] packet) [0x00074] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs:161 
  at OpenRA.Network.OrderManager+<TickImmediate>c__AnonStorey0.<>m__0 (Int32 clientId, System.Byte[] packet) [0x00050] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs:119 
  at OpenRA.Network.ReplayRecorderConnection+<Receive>c__AnonStorey0.<>m__0 (Int32 client, System.Byte[] data) [0x00094] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/ReplayRecorderConnection.cs:95 
  at OpenRA.Network.EchoConnection.Receive (System.Action`2 packetFn) [0x00055] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/Connection.cs:103 
  at OpenRA.Network.ReplayRecorderConnection.Receive (System.Action`2 packetFn) [0x00027] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/ReplayRecorderConnection.cs:82 
  at OpenRA.Network.OrderManager.TickImmediate () [0x000c0] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Network/OrderManager.cs:112 
  at OpenRA.Sync+<CheckSyncUnchanged>c__AnonStorey0.<>m__0 () [0x00007] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Sync.cs:168 
  at OpenRA.Sync.CheckSyncUnchanged[Boolean] (OpenRA.World world, System.Func`1 fn) [0x00044] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Sync.cs:185 
  at OpenRA.Sync.CheckSyncUnchanged (OpenRA.World world, System.Action fn) [0x0001b] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Sync.cs:168 
  at OpenRA.Game.InnerLogicTick (OpenRA.Network.OrderManager orderManager) [0x0011c] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Game.cs:462 
  at OpenRA.Game.LogicTick () [0x0004e] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Game.cs:507 
  at OpenRA.Game.Loop () [0x000d4] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Game.cs:631 
  at OpenRA.Game.Run () [0x00042] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Game.cs:671 
  at OpenRA.Program.Run (System.String[] args) [0x00011] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Support/Program.cs:111 
  at OpenRA.Program.Main (System.String[] args) [0x00050] in /home/matthias/Entwicklung/OpenRA/OpenRA.Game/Support/Program.cs:39
```

I only got 1 syncreport.log for obvious reasons: https://gist.github.com/Mailaender/ff047a4d04d175ca0cab

> I played this with two local clients and many bots which desynced the game

This PR changes the code for issuing bot orders, which only runs on one client.  It shouldn't be able to desync.
FWIW, I just had a 45 minute AI match with a second client as spectator and didn't get any desyncs.
This latest iteration works very well. In several test games I didn't notice any mis-behaving, passive AIs anymore. The code changes are straight-forward, too. :+1:
In that case I stumbled upon another d2k mod exclusive desync I guess :(
That's good to hear. I'm guessing this has been implemented in the latest playtest release (20150808)? Will give it a go later. Thanks again!
Yes, though we are probably not done here.
